DOC.brief_summary: Patients who undergo chemotherapy for leukemia will receive study medication for prevention of fungal infections. The study investigates the safety and tolerability of two different dosages, the efficacy in prevention of fungal diseases.
DOC.brief_title: Safety, Efficacy and Pharmacokinetics of an Antifungal in Patients Undergoing Chemotherapy
DOC.detailed_description: Patients with Acute Myeloid Leukemia who undergo aggressive chemotherapy are due to immunosuppression susceptible to infections, including fungal infections. As the failure rate in the treatment of invasive fungal infections is high, prophylaxis is frequently recommended. This open label study investigates the safety and tolerability of two different dosages of a water soluble azole antifungal, as well as the efficacy in prevention of invasive fungal infections and pharmacokinetic data.
DOC.criteria: diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia patients entering first induction treatment; or subsequent chemotherapy if no prior invasive fungal infection was observed expected to be neutropenic for >9 and <28 days after enrollment women of childbearing potential must have a negative pregnancy test patients who received any systemic antifungal therapy for more than 72 hours prior to first administration of study medication.
